title: Ticket #2755: IPv6: Hunt down hand-rolled sinful string implementations
description:
With the addition of IPv6, reading and writing sinful strings is not easy, and the various one-off implementations doing so are dangerous. These need to be cleaned up, almost always by using condor_sockaddr::from_sinful or condor_sockaddr::to_sinful, both from /src/condor_include/condor_sockaddr.h

  • ReliSock::serialize in /src/condor_io/reli_sock.cpp around line 863. It looks suspiciously like what is claimed to be a sinful string is actually a bare IP address, possibly with a port.
    - Not a problem. (There was a too short buffer, however.)
  • SafeSock::serialize in /src/condor_io/safe_sock.cpp around line 815. Almost identical to the ReliSock::serialize code path.
    - Not a problem. (There was a too short buffer, however.)
  • serialize_input in /src/condor_power/power.cpp line 236. Guaranteed to fail in IPv6.
    #3071 changed this to a const string.
